body:
Thanks for your report @Vistritium . I took the liberty of moving it from the 'akka-http' repo to the 'akka' repo, as I can reproduce your issue with plain Akka Streams (without Akka HTTP) as well. 

Interesting observations are that when I `.flush()` the outputStream before closing, or when I create a whole new `Source` instead of materializing the same one multiple times the error appears to go away. This may be just a matter of timing/coincidence though, I haven't seen anything that points to a real problem in those areas yet.

Hmm, this could be a race between the `write()` going though the `dataQueue` and into the `downstreamCallback`, and the `close()` going directly to the `upstreamCallback`: what if `upstreamCallback` is called between the moment the data has been read from the dataQueue and the moment that the data is passed to the `downstreamCallback`?

@schmitch you seem to have done some work in this area, do you know how we intended to safeguard against this?

hm... i actually touched the file a long time ago, so I'm not sure if I can be that helpful, but I will try.

if `flush()` would help, we could maybe also try to flush any data before close, because just from looking it looks like that if `close()` is called, while the dataQueue is not empty it will drop it: https://github.com/akka/akka/blob/master/akka-stream/src/main/scala/akka/stream/impl/io/OutputStreamSourceStage.scala#L136 (`unblockUpstream` is never called in that case)

also is there any error which might get swallowed? i.e. inside the stream or when calling close?

repository.name: akka-core
repository.description: A platform to build and run apps that are elastic, agile, and resilient. SDK, libraries, and hosted environments.

body: Unfortunately flushing before closing does not reliably work either, since there is still a chance that both the flush and the close are handled before `downstreamCallback` is invoked with the data read from the queue.
